subject: RE: [junit] How to test protected and private methods/ fields?

messageBody:
Hi all.

I was completely wrong-footed yesterday about the scope of protected
access. It turns out (and apologies to those of you who already know this)
that protected members are visible to all other classes in the same
_package_ as well as any subclasses, which I spent quite a lot of yesterday
vehemently refuting, until I had the language definition shoved under my nose.

Anyway, I thought I'd share my humiliating defeat with you because it
provides a nice solution to the problem of testing protected methods - you
just test them from a test class within the same package. (I really like
the earlier suggestion of having the test cases in the same package but a
different directory - hadn't occurred to me before.)

Now this is only my own development practice, but I tend to use: public
access for, umm, public methods, protected for methods which I expect to be
overridden by subclasses (and probably made public), or which I expect to
be used by subclasses, and private methods purely as helpers for public or
protected methods elsewhere in the class, which means these private methods
can be tested indirectly anyway by testing combinations of the other methods.

Hope that helps,
Dan.
